Michael Bay’s Ambulance is one of those action thrillers that grabs you from the opening moments and refuses to let go, delivering a relentless two-hour ride driven by chaos, desperation, and tightly wound character dynamics. What makes the film immediately stand out is the surprising emotional current running beneath the explosions and Bay-isms. Instead of relying solely on spectacle, the story uses tension, anxiety, and human stakes to elevate what could have been a standard heist-gone-wrong narrative. The film wastes no time setting its frantic pace, and the intensity practically becomes a character of its own.

Jake Gyllenhaal is the standout force, turning in one of his most energetic and unhinged performances in years. He grounds his character in charisma, unpredictability, and a sense of manic urgency that pushes the film forward. Opposite him, Yahya Abdul-Mateen II delivers a more restrained and heartfelt performance, creating a dynamic that feels both volatile and deeply personal. Their chemistry is exactly what the movie needs: a push-and-pull relationship that never stops shifting, keeping the audience unsure who to trust or root for at any given moment.

The direction is undeniably Bay—fast cuts, sweeping drone shots, loud sound design—but in Ambulance, those stylistic choices work better than they have in years. Bay uses the confined space of the ambulance to build claustrophobia while balancing it with massive city-wide chase sequences that turn Los Angeles into a kinetic playground. There’s a rhythm to the chaos, and even when the visuals become overwhelming, they maintain a clear purpose: heightening the desperation of the characters who are spiraling further out of control.

The screenplay, however, occasionally struggles to keep up with the film’s energy. There are moments where the dialogue stumbles or the pacing becomes uneven, and certain plot points feel more convoluted than necessary. But even when the narrative wavers, it recovers quickly thanks to the film’s sheer commitment to momentum. The twists and turns don’t always land cleanly, yet they consistently keep the audience guessing about who’s making which decision and how the situation could possibly escalate further.

What ultimately makes Ambulance work is how fully it embraces its own intensity. The film is unapologetically loud, chaotic, and sometimes messy, but it never pretends to be anything else. The heart of the story—loyalty, desperation, and moral conflict—remains strong enough to give the action weight. Whether the characters are arguing, panicking, or fighting for survival, the film always pulls viewers directly into their uncertainty and adrenaline.

As wild as it is, Ambulance succeeds at being a thrilling, surprisingly engaging action film with big performances, sharp direction, and a sense of urgency that rarely lets up. It may have its flaws, and at times the story bounces so quickly that it borders on disorienting, but the overall experience is undeniably entertaining. For viewers craving a high-energy, tension-soaked ride with standout acting and bold stylistic choices, this is absolutely a film worth watching.
